H0.text: Following success at the 1979 election whose party conference speeech included the lines 'you turn if you want to, the lady's not for turning'. Margaret Thatcher

H1.text: Following success at the 1979 election whose party conference speeech included the lines 'you turn if you want to, the lady's not for turning'. Edith Summerskill

H2.text: Following success at the 1979 election whose party conference speeech included the lines 'you turn if you want to, the lady's not for turning'. Barbara Castle

H3.text: Following success at the 1979 election whose party conference speeech included the lines 'you turn if you want to, the lady's not for turning'. Mrs T

A4.text: At the 1980 Conservative Party conference, Thatcher addressed the issue directly with a speech written by the playwright Ronald Millar, that notably included the following lines: 'You turn if you want to. The lady's not for turning.'

A5.text: The Conservatives won a 44-seat majority in the House of Commons, and Thatcher became the first female British prime minister.
